questions.text: The parents of an infant with cleft lip and palate (infant shown in the image) visit a genetic counsellor to discuss the chance that a similar birth defect will occur in their future offspring. In addition to teratogen exposure and multifactorial inheritance, which of the following is an important cause of this error of morphogenesis?
questions.solution:
Cleft lip and cleft palate exemplify multifactorial inheritance in which multiple genes interact with various environmental factors to produce disease.

  • On the 35th day of gestation, the frontal prominence fuses with the maxillary process to form the upper lip.
  • Disturbances in gene expression at this time (hereditary or environmental) à interference with proper fusion and result in cleft lip, with or without cleft palate.
  • In addition to multifactorial inheritance, this developmental anomaly may be part of a malformation syndrome caused by teratogens (e.g., rubella and anticonvulsants).
  • That is often encountered in children with chromosomal abnormalities (correct answer).
  • Seen in PATAU SYNDROME (TRISOMY 13).
  • The incidence of cleft lip, with or without cleft palate, is 1 in 1,000, and the incidence of cleft palate alone is 1 in 2,500.
  • If one child is born with a cleft lip, the chances are 4% that the second child will exhibit the same defect.
  • If the first two children are affected, the risk of cleft lip increases to 9% for the third child. The more severe the anatomical defect, the greater the probability of transmitting cleft lip will be.
  • Whereas 75% of cases of cleft lip occur in boys, the sons of women with cleft lip have a four times higher risk of acquiring the defect than the sons of affected fathers.
  • None of the other choices are associated with a significantly increased risk of cleft lip.

Key Takeaways: Cleft lip and palate are primarily caused by multifactorial inheritance, where both genetic and environmental factors play a role. Chromosomal abnormalities, such as Patau syndrome (trisomy 13), can also cause these defects. The risk of recurrence in future pregnancies increases with the severity of the defect and is higher if the first child is affected.

questions.text: All of the following techniques can detect genomic abnormalities without prior knowledge of one or few specific altered chromosomal regions in test, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
FISH requires prior knowledge of the one or few specific chromosomal regions suspected of being altered in the test sample. However,

  • Genomic abnormalities can be detected without prior knowledge by using microarray technology to perform a global genomic survey.
  • First-generation platforms :
  • Comparative genomic hybridization (CGH)
  • Newer platforms :
  • Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping

Key Takeaways: FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) requires prior knowledge of the specific chromosomal region being investigated, as it targets and binds to known sequences. Unlike techniques like array CGH or SNP genotyping, which detect genomic abnormalities without prior knowledge, FISH is a targeted method and can only identify specific alterations if the region of interest is already suspected.

questions.text: Epigenetics is a study of___
questions.solution:
• Epigenetics is defined as the study of heritable chemical modification of DNA or chromatin that does not alter the protein-encoding DNA sequence itself.
  • Examples of such Modifications include methylation of DNA and methylation and acetylation of histones
  • Choice A defines the genetics
  • Choice B defines the mutation
  • Choice C defines the genomics
  • Choice D defines epigenetics

Key Takeaways:

  • Genetics is the study of DNA sequences.
  • Mutation refers to changes in the genetic sequence.
  • Genomics is the study of the entire genome.
  • Epigenetics focuses on chemical modifications of DNA and histones that don't alter the DNA sequence itself, such as DNA methylation and histones.

questions.text: A 4 year old with a history of seizure disorder and developmental delay is referred to a geneticist for consideration of genetic testing. His paediatrician noticed that she is very hyperexcitable and is constantly laughing and smiling. His parents also report poor feeding, sleep disturbance and tremors. He is currently taking anti epileptic medication . Which of the following abnormality is seen most commonly in this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with Angelman syndrome are born with a deletion of the same chromosomal region derived from their mothers.

  • Patients with Angelman syndrome also have intellectual disability, but in addition they present with microcephaly, ataxic gait, seizures, and inappropriate laughter. Because of their laughter and ataxia, they have been referred to as 'happy puppets.'
  • In Angelman syndrome, the affected gene is a ubiquitin ligase that is involved in catalysing the transfer of activated ubiquitin to target protein substrates.
  • The gene, called UBE3A, maps within the 15q12 region, is imprinted on the paternal chromosome, and is expressed from the maternal allele primarily in specific regions of the brain. Absence of UBE3A inhibits synapse formation and synaptic plasticity.
  • The imprinting is tissue-specific in that UBE3A is expressed from both alleles in most tissues.
  • Choice A suggests Fragile X syndrome
  • Choice B suggests Prader Willi syndrome
  • Choice C suggests Angelman syndrome
  • Choice D suggests Marfan syndrome

Key Takeaways:

  • Angelman syndrome: Maternal UBE3A gene deletion, causing seizures, developmental delay, ataxia, and inappropriate laughter.
  • Fragile X: FMR1 gene deletion, intellectual disability and behavioural issues.
  • Prader-Willi: Paternal 15q12 deletion, marked by hypotonia and obesity.
  • Marfan syndrome: FBN1 gene mutation, causing tall stature and cardiovascular issues.

choices.text: Formation of an abnormal metabolic end-product

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman complains of recurrent bone pain and increasing abdominal girth. Physical examination reveals massive hepatosplenomegaly. Radiologic studies reveal several radiolucent bone defects. A bone marrow biopsy discloses enlarged cells with a fibrillar appearance reminiscent of 'wrinkled tissue paper.' The cause of the pathogenesis of hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain in the patient is?
questions.solution:
Gaucher disease

  • It is characterized by the accumulation of glucosylceramide, primarily in the lysosomes of macrophages. The underlying abnormality in Gaucher disease is a deficiency in glucocerebrosidase, a type of lysosomal acid β-glucosidase.
  • The hallmark → GAUCHER CELLS, which are lipid- laden macrophages that are characteristically present in the red pulp of the spleen, liver sinusoids, lymph nodes, lungs, and bone marrow.
  • These cells are derived from the resident macrophages in the respective organs (e.g., Kupffer cells in the liver and alveolar macrophages in the lung).
  • Glucosylceramide is a common core structure for membrane glycosphingolipids.
  • The glucosylceramide that accumulates in Gaucher cells in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes derives principally from the catabolism of senescent leukocytes.
  • The membranes of these cells are rich in the cerebrosides, and when their degradation is blocked by the deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, the intermediate metabolite, glucosylceramide, accumulates.

Key Takeaways: Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency in glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in lysosomes. This results in the formation of Gaucher cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages with a "wrinkled tissue paper" appearance, found in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and other organs. Symptoms include hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and radiolucent bone defects, all due to the build-up of unmetabolized glucosylceramide. The primary pathogenesis of these manifestations is the accumulation of unmetabolized substrate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent form of familial mental retardation, mainly in males with huge ears and macro-orchidism?
questions.solution:
Males with Fragile X Syndrome have marked intellectual disability.

  • They Have a characteristic physical phenotype that includes a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears, and large testicles (macro-orchidism).
  • Hyperextensible joints, a high arched palate, and mitral valve prolapse noted in some patients mimic a connective tissue disorder.
  • The most distinctive feature is macro-orchidism, which is observed in at least 90% of affected postpubertal males.
  • Neurologic and neuropsychiatric manifestations +
  • Epilepsy in 30% of cases
  • Aggressive behaviour in 90% of cases
  • Autism spectrum disorder (includes several conditions such as autism and Asperger syndrome)
  • Anxiety disorder/hyperactivity disorder.
  • The latter two affect 50% to 75% of males with FXS.
  • 2-5% patients diagnosed first with non-syndromic autism have a mutation in the FMR1 gene.
  • As with other X-linked diseases, FXS affects males predominantly.
  • Analysis of several pedigrees, however, reveals some patterns of transmission not typically associated with Other X-linked recessive disorders

Key Takeaways: Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited intellectual disability, especially in males. Key features include a long face, large ears, macro-orchidism, and hyperextensible joints. Neurological symptoms often include epilepsy, aggressive behaviour, and autism. It is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy came to pediatric dentistry department with the chief complaints of multiple decayed tooth since 2-3 years with no associated pain or swelling. Natal history revealed that he did not cry at the time of birth and aspirated meconium. There was a history of seizures at three months of age, hypotonia, speech impairment and intellectual disability. He had right undescended testis for which he got operated but the surgery was unsuccessful. On clinical examination, the boy seems obese and short stature, small hands and feet. He has typical fish mouth appearance. The clinical image is given below. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Prader Willi syndrome

  • Multisystemic genetic disorder
  • Failed expression of paternally inherited genes on chromosome 15q11-13.
  • 70% have a paternally derived deletion of 15q11-13
  • 25% have maternal disomy of chromosome 15
  • 2-5% have imprinting defects
  • Patients have intellectual disability, short stature, hypotonia, hyperphagia, obesity, small hands and feet, hypogonadism, fish mouth appearance (down turned corners of the mouth)
  • Behavioural problems :- short attention span, stubbornness, temper tantrums.

Key Takeaways: Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the loss of paternal genes on chromosome 15q11-13. Key features include intellectual disability, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. Patients often have a characteristic fish-mouth appearance, behavioural issues like temper tantrums, and a history of hyperphagia. It can also be associated with seizures and undescended testes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common finding in spontaneously aborted fetus?
questions.solution:
Polyploidy is a fatal cytogenetic anomaly that results in pregnancy loss.

  • A miscarriage is defined as the loss of pregnancy before 20 weeks of estimated gestational age.

Key Takeaways: Polyploidy, an extra set of chromosomes, is a common cause of spontaneous abortion. It leads to miscarriage due to the fatal nature of this cytogenetic anomaly.

questions.text: Which of the following mutation is seen in marfan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Marfan Syndrome

  • Marfan syndrome results from an INHERITED DEFECT IN AN EXTRACELLULAR GLYCOPROTEIN CALLED FIBRILLIN-1.
  • There are two fundamental mechanisms by which loss of fibrillin leads to the clinical manifestations of Marfan syndrome:
  • loss of structural support in microfibril-rich connective tissue
  • excessive activation of transforming growth factor (TGF)-β signalling.
  • Fibrillin is the major component of microfibrils found in the extracellular matrix. They are particularly abundant in the aorta, ligaments, and the ciliary zonules that support the lens; these tissues are prominently affected in Marfan syndrome.
  • Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms, fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN1 and FBN2, mapped on chromosomes 15q21.1 and 5q23.31, respectively.
  • Mutations of FBN1 → Marfan syndrome;
  • Mutations of the related FBN2 → congenital contractural arachnodactyly, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by skeletal abnormalities.
  • Mutational analysis has revealed close to 1000 distinct mutations of the FBN1 gene in individuals with Marfan syndrome. Most of these are missense mutations that give rise to abnormal fibrillin-1.
  • The major tissues affected are the skeleton, eyes, and cardiovascular system.
  • Clinical features may include tall stature, long fingers, bilateral subluxation of lens, mitral valve prolapse, aortic aneurysm, and aortic dissection.

Key Takeaways: Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes fibrillin-1, a key component of connective tissue. The mutation leads to structural defects, particularly affecting the cardiovascular system, eyes, and skeleton.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presents with a history of viral and fungal infections and has calcium of 5.8 mg/dL. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Patients with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia, With resultant T-cell immunodeficiency, parathyroid hypoplasia giving rise to hypocalcemia, a variety of cardiac malformations affecting the outflow tract, and mild facial anomalies. Atopic disorders (e.g., allergic rhinitis) and autoimmunity (e.g., thrombocytopenia) may also be seen.
  • Deletion of 22q11.2.
  • Diagnosis - FISH

Key Takeaways: DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia (T-cell deficiency), parathyroid hypoplasia (causing hypocalcaemia), cardiac malformations, and mild facial anomalies. It is caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2. Diagnosis is confirmed by FISH.

questions.text: Which of the following deficient enzyme is seen in Gaucher disease?
questions.solution:
• Gaucher disease results from lack of the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase and accumulation of glucocerebroside in mononuclear phagocytic cells.
  • In the most common, type I variant, affected phagocytes become enlarged (Gaucher cells) and accumulate in liver, spleen, and bone marrow, causing hepatosplenomegaly and bone erosion.
  • Types II and III are characterized by variable neuronal involvement. Gaucher disease has a strong association with Parkinson disease.

Key Takeaways: Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in phagocytic cells. This results in hepatosplenomegaly, bone erosion, and, in some cases, neuronal involvement. It is associated with Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A mutation in the NPC 1 or 2 gene is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Niemann-Pick Disease Type C

  • Niemann-Pick disease type C is distinct at the biochemical and genetic levels and is more common than types A and B combined.
  • Mutations in two related genes, NPC1 and NPC2, can give rise to Niemann-Pick disease type C, with NPC1 being responsible for 95% of cases.
  • It is due to a primary defect in nonenzymatic lipid transport.
  • NPC1 is membrane bound, whereas NPC2 is soluble.
  • Both are involved in the transport of free cholesterol from the lysosomes to the cytoplasm.
  • clinically heterogeneous.
  • It may present as hydrops fetalis and stillbirth, as neonatal hepatitis, or, most commonly, as a chronic form characterized by progressive neurologic damage.
  • The clinical course is marked by ataxia, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, dystonia, dysarthria, and psychomotor regression.

Key Takeaways: Niemann-Pick disease type C is caused by mutations in the NPC1 or NPC2 genes, with NPC1 responsible for 95% of cases. This disorder involves defective lipid transport, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol in lysosomes. It presents with progressive neurologic symptoms, including ataxia, gaze palsy, dystonia, and psychomotor regression.

questions.text: Mcardle disease shows which of the following feature?
questions.solution:
• Massive Cardiomegaly is seen in pompe disease type 2. (Choice A)
  • Hyperlipidemia and hypoglycemia is seen in von gierke disease. (Choice B & C)

Key Takeaways: McArdle disease is characterized by myoglobinuria due to muscle weakness and damage from impaired glycogen breakdown. It is caused by a deficiency in muscle glycogen phosphorylase. The other options (massive cardiomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and hypoglycemia) are seen in different glycogen storage diseases.

questions.text: Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by all of the following mutations in the genes, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
In familial hypercholesterolemia, the following genes get mutated.

Mutations in LDLR gene →

  • Heterozygotes with FH due to mutation in the LDLR gene possess only 50% of the normal number of high-affinity LDL receptors because they have only one normal gene. As a result of this defect in transport, the catabolism of LDL by the receptor-dependent pathways is impaired, and the plasma level of LDL increases two- to three-fold.
  • Homozygotes have virtually no normal LDL receptors in their cells and have much higher levels of circulating LDL.
  • In addition to defective LDL clearance, both the homozygotes and the heterozygotes have increased synthesis of LDL. The increased synthesis that contributes to hypercholesterolemia also results from a lack of LDL receptors (see Fig. 5.6). As mentioned above, IDL, the immediate precursor of plasma LDL, also uses hepatic LDL receptors (apoB/E receptors) for its transport into the liver. In FH, impaired IDL transport into the liver secondarily diverts a greater proportion of plasma IDL into the precursor pool for plasma LDL.

Mutations in gene encoding ApoB → Since ApoB on the surface of LDL particles is the ligand for LDL receptors, mutant ApoB reduces the binding of LDL molecules with LDL receptors. This compromise in the binding of LDL particles to its receptors increases serum LDL cholesterol.

Activating mutation in the PCSK9 gene → Reduces the number of LDL receptors on the cell surface because of their increased degradation during the recycling process.

Key Takeaways: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is caused by mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLR) gene, ApoB protein, and the PCSK9 gene, which affect LDL cholesterol clearance. Mutations in Apo C protein are not associated with FH. In FH, LDL receptor defects reduce LDL clearance, increasing plasma LDL levels. PCSK9 mutations further exacerbate the condition by promoting LDL receptor degradation.

questions.text: Wrong about karyotyping from the following?
questions.solution:
• Karyotypes are prepared from mitotic cells that have been arrested in the metaphase or prometaphase portion of the cell cycle, when chromosomes assume their most condensed conformations. (Choice A& B)
  • A variety of tissue types can be used as a source of these cells.
    • For cancer diagnoses → tumor biopsies or bone marrow samples.
    • For other diagnoses → karyotypes are often generated from peripheral blood specimens or a skin biopsy.
    • For prenatal diagnosis → amniotic fluid or chorionic villus specimens are used as the source of cells.
  • In G-banding, the variant of Giemsa staining most commonly used. (Choice C)
  • Metaphase chromosomes are first treated briefly with trypsin, an enzyme that degrades proteins, before the chromosomes are stained with Giemsa. Trypsin partially digests some of the chromosomal proteins, thereby relaxing the chromatin structure and allowing the Giemsa dye access to the DNA.
  • Ideogram is the diagrammatic representation of the karyotype of an individual. (Choice D)
  • Karyogram is the actual picture of the chromosome set of a cell, arranged in homologous pairs and in series of decreasing size. 2 types: symmetric and asymmetric.
  • In the following image shows both Ideogram (left) and karyogram (right)

Key Takeaways: Karyotyping requires cells to be in division, specifically metaphase, not telophase. Giemsa stain is used for chromosome analysis, and the results are often represented as an ideogram. The cell division arrest occurs at metaphase, not telophase. Karyograms display actual chromosome sets, while ideograms are diagrammatic representations.

questions.text: In Fabry disease which of the following enzyme is deficient?
questions.solution:
Fabry Disease is an X-linked genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in the lysosomes. When this enzyme is deficient, Gb3 accumulates in various tissues, including the kidneys, heart, skin, and nervous system, leading to characteristic symptoms such as painful neuropathy, angiokeratomas, renal failure, and cardiovascular problems.

Why the other options are incorrect:-

  • A) Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, blindness, and cherry-red spots on the retina. It is not associated with Fabry disease.
  • C) Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of sphingomyelinase leads to Niemann-Pick disease, which causes neurodegeneration, hepatosplenomegaly, and lipid accumulation in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. This is not the enzyme deficient in Fabry disease.
  • D) Glucocerebrosidase: Deficiency of glucocerebrosidase leads to Gaucher disease, which results in hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and fatigue, but not the same symptoms as Fabry disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fabry disease is caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency.
  • Symptoms include neuropathy, angiokeratomas, renal and cardiovascular issues.
  • It is a lysosomal storage disorder with X-linked inheritance.

questions.text: Match the following classification of LDL receptor mutation on abnormal function of mutant protein?
questions.solution:
• More than 2000 mutations involving the LDL receptor gene, including DNA copy number variations, insertions, deletions, and missense and nonsense mutations, have been identified.
    • These can be classified into six groups.
  • CLASS I MUTATIONS → are relatively uncommon and lead to a complete failure of synthesis of the LDL receptor protein (null allele).
  • CLASS II MUTATIONS → are fairly common; they encode LDL receptor proteins that accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum because their folding defects make it impossible for them to be transported to the Golgi complex.
  • CLASS III MUTATIONS → affect the ApoB binding site of the receptor; the mutant LDL receptors reach the cell surface but fail to bind LDL or do so poorly.
  • CLASS IV MUTATIONS → encode LDL receptors that are synthesized and transported to the cell surface efficiently. They bind LDL normally, but they fail to localize in coated pits, and hence the bound LDL is not internalized.
  • CLASS V MUTATIONS → encode LDL receptors that are expressed on the cell surface, can bind LDL, and can be internalized; however, the pH-dependent dissociation of the receptor and the bound LDL fails to occur. Such receptors are trapped in the endosome, where they are degraded, and hence they fail to recycle to the cell surface.
  • CLASS VI MUTATIONS → result in the failure of initial targeting of the LDL receptor to the basolateral membrane.

Key Takeaways:

  • Class I: No LDL receptor synthesis.
  • Class II: Defective folding, no transport to Golgi.
  • Class III: Poor binding to ApoB.
  • Class IV: Receptor binds LDL but fails to internalize.
  • Class V: Receptor fails to dissociate from LDL in endosome.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy shows progressive weakness, mental Deterioration, and loss of vision. Laboratory studies Demonstrate decreased activity of hexosaminidase A. The child eventually becomes blind and dies at 3 years of age. If the parents of the child have a total of four sons and two daughters, then, on average, how many of their children may be expected to be asymptomatic (i.e., Silent) carriers of this gene mutation?
questions.solution:
TAY-SACHS DISEASE - Autosomal recessive disorder

  • Catastrophic infantile variant of a class of lysosomal storage diseases known as GM2 gangliosidoses.
  • This ganglioside is deposited in neurons of the central Nervous system due to a failure of lysosomal degradation and accumulation of an unmetabolized substrate.
  • Gangliosides are Glycosphingolipids that are present in the outer leaflet of the Plasma membrane, particularly in neurons.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive.
  • In autosomal recessive diseases, on average, half of the offspring are expected to be heterozygotes and silent Carriers of the gene mutation.

Key Takeaways: Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, and in such conditions, half of the offspring are typically expected to be heterozygotes and silent carriers of the gene mutation. Given that the parents in this scenario have six children (four sons and two daughters), on average, three of them would be expected to be asymptomatic carriers of the mutation.

questions.text: All are examples of autosomal recessive diseases, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disease.

Key Takeaways: Autosomal recessive diseases require two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) for the disease to manifest. Examples include sickle cell anemia, galactosemia, and cystic fibrosis. In contrast, Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant condition, meaning only one copy of the mutated gene is needed for the disease to present.
